children.name: to reduce the number, amount, price, or size of st
reduce
children.definition: /rɪˈdjuːsǁrɪˈduːs/  to make something less in amount or level:giảm
examples: ▪ i was hoping they would reduce the price a little.
greatly/significantly/dramatically reduce: giảm đáng kể
▪ you can greatly reduce your heating bills by using low-energy heaters.
dramatically/drastically reduce: giảm đột ngột, trầm trọng
▪ their income has been drastically reduced.
reduce something by half/10%/2 years etc: giảm cái gì đó một nửa / 10% / 2 năm vv
▪ the new road will reduce traffic through the town by 30%.
▪ benefits will be reduced by $50 for each child who fails to attend school.
reduced[adjective]được giảm
▪ most airlines offer reduced prices for children.

children.name: lower
children.definition: /ˈləʊəʳ/  to reduce an amount, limit, or level - use this especially in writing about business or technical subjects:giảm
examples: ▪ after 20 minutes, lower the temperature to 200 degrees.
▪ the bundesbank is under pressure to lower interest rates.

children.name: cut
children.definition: /kʌt/  to reduce something by a lot, especially prices, time, or money:cắt giảm
examples: ▪ the new system is aimed at cutting the average waiting time.
cut something by half/several weeks/ten per cent etc
cắt giảm cái gì đó một nửa / vài tuần / mười phần trăm vv
▪ because of the recession, salaries in the advertising industry have been cut by a half.
▪ the mortgage insurance agency has cut costs by $2000 over the last 3 years, making it easier for people to buy homes.
cut something from/to something
cắt giảm cái gì đó từ / sang cái gì đó
▪ his annual leave has been cut from six weeks to just three.

children.name: turn down
children.definition: /ˌtɜːʳn ˈdaʊn/  to reduce the level of sound, heat, light etc, especially by turning a control:giảm xuống
examples: turn something down:giảm xuống cái gì đó
▪ could you turn the lights down - it’s too bright in here.
turn down something:giảm xuống cái gì đó
▪ the weather wasn’t as cold, so we decided to turn down the central heating.
turn something down slightly/a little/a bit:giảm xuống cái gì đó một chút
▪ would you mind turning the volume down a little?

children.name: decrease
children.definition: /dɪˈkriːs/  to reduce something, especially by a fairly small amount or number:giảm xuống
examples: ▪ various methods are being explored in order to decrease the volume of traffic on our roads.
▪ better health education should help to decrease the incidence of heart disease.
▪ use of the new nets has significantly decreased the number of dolphins killed accidentally each year.

children.name: slash
children.definition: /slæʃ/  informal to reduce prices by a very large amount - used especially in advertisements and newspapers:cắt bớt
examples: ▪ american car manufacturers have started slashing prices in an effort to stimulate sales.
▪ public spending has been slashed over the past two years.
slash something by 10%/half/75% etc:cắt bớt cái gì đó10%/một nửa/75% ...
▪ come to our summer sale, where prices have been slashed by up to 75%.

children.name: knock down
children.definition: /ˌnɒk ˈdaʊnǁˌnɑːk-/  informal to reduce the price of something by a large amount, especially in order to make it easier to sell:hạ, giảm giá
examples: knock down something:hạ, giảm giá cái gì đó
▪ shops are knocking down prices in an effort to increase sales.
knock something down:hạ, giảm giá cái gì đó
▪ in the end he knocked the price down to £70.

children.name: halve
children.definition: /hɑːvǁhæv/  to reduce something by half:giảm một nửa
examples: ▪ the overseas aid budget has been almost halved, from $18m to just over $10m.

children.name: roll back
children.definition: /ˌrəʊl ˈbæk/  american to reduce prices:hạ, giảm giá
examples: roll back something:hạ, giảm giá cái gì đó
▪ most of the big downtown stores have rolled back their prices to dispose of winter stock.
roll something back:hạ, giảm giá cái gì đó
▪ rather than roll prices back, the company negotiated pay increases that ranged between 10 and 15 percent.

children.name: to reduce pain, worry, or unpleasant feelings
reduce
children.definition: /rɪˈdjuːsǁrɪˈduːs/ giảm bớt
examples: ▪ they gave him drugs to reduce the pain.
▪ prompt action can often reduce the severity of shock in road accident victims.
▪ miriam finds that yoga and meditation help her in reducing stress.
greatly/significantly/dramatically reduce:giảm bớt đáng kể
▪ stopping smoking can significantly reduce your risk of suffering a heart attack.

children.name: lessen
children.definition: /ˈlesən/  to slightly reduce pain or bad feelings:làm giảm đi
examples: ▪ he shifted his position a little, in order to lessen the pain in his leg.
▪ everyone has their own ideas about the best way to lessen jet lag.
▪ boys are more likely to smoke to relieve stress than girls are.

children.name: lighten
children.definition: /ˈlaɪtn/  to reduce the amount of work or worry that someone has:giảm bớt, làm nhẹ đi
examples: lighten somebody’s load/workload:giảm bớt, làm nhẹ đi lượng công việc của ai đó
▪ maybe we should hire another secretary to lighten barbara’s workload.

children.name: relieve
children.definition: /rɪˈliːv/  to make pain or feelings less unpleasant:làm nhẹ bớt, giảm bớt
examples: ▪ peppermint has long been regarded as a plant that can relieve indigestion.
▪ magnetic board games can help relieve the boredom of long car journeys for kids.
▪ harry attempted a couple of jokes to relieve the tension of the occasion.
relief/rɪˈliːf/ [uncountable noun]sự giảm nhẹ, sự bớt đi
▪ massage is excellent for the relief of stress.
▪ various methods can be used for pain relief during childbirth.

children.name: ease
children.definition: /iːz/  to reduce pain or unpleasant feelings and make someone feel happier or more comfortable:làm bớt căng
examples: ▪ rod rubbed his jaw to ease the pain a little.
▪ the arrival of the others eased her embarrassment slightly.

children.name: alleviate
children.definition: /əˈliːvieɪt/  formal to reduce pain, make a problem less serious, or reduce feelings such as being bored or anxious:làm dịu, làm khuây
examples: ▪ you can’t cure a common cold, but you can alleviate the symptoms.
▪ western aid has helped to alleviate the situation in northern india.
alleviation/əˌliːviˈeɪʃən/ [uncountable noun]:sựlàm dịu, làm khuây
▪ the alleviation of pain

children.name: deaden/dull
children.definition: /ˈdedn, dʌl/  to reduce physical pain or emotional problems, especially with the result that you feel nothing at all:làm giảm, làm dịu, làm nhẹ
examples: ▪ they gave me a local anaesthetic to deaden the pain.
▪ it was impossible not to think about her baby, but the drugs dulled her panic.

children.name: take the edge off
children.definition: /ˌteɪk ði ˈedʒ ɒf/  to make something such as pain, hunger, or a shock slightly less unpleasant or upsetting:làm bớt
examples: ▪ i took a couple of painkillers, which took the edge off the pain.
▪ knowing that peter was close by took the edge off my anxiety for my grandson.

children.name: allay
children.definition: /əˈleɪ/ làm dịu
examples: allay somebody’s fears/concern/suspicions etc : làm dịu nỗi sợ hãi / lo lắng / nghi ngờ của ai đó vv
formal to make someone much less frightened, concerned etc:
▪ the government is anxious to allay public fears over the safety of beef.
▪ showing her his identity card went some way towards allaying her suspicions.

children.name: to reduce the amount of st that you eat, drink, or use
cut down
children.definition: /ˌkʌt ˈdaʊn/  if you cut down on food, alcoholic drink, or tobacco, you eat, drink, or smoke less of it, especially in order to lose weight or to improve your health:cắt giảm
examples: ▪ if you can’t give up smoking completely, at least try to cut down.
cut down on:cắt giảm
▪ i’m trying to cut down on meat.

children.name: reduce
children.definition: /rɪˈdjuːsǁrɪˈduːs/  to reduce the amount of something that you eat, drink, or use. reduce is more formal than cut down:giảm , hạ
examples: ▪ doctors are urging people to reduce the amount of salt in their diet.
▪ supermarkets can help promote healthy eating habits by reducing the amount of sugar and fat in their products.

children.name: when a company reduces its activities, the amount it spends etc
scale down
children.definition: also scale back american /ˌskeɪl ˈdaʊn, ˌskeɪl ˈbæk/  to reduce something, such as the size of an organization or a plan, so that it is still operating but on a smaller level:giảm bớt
examples: scale down/back something:giảm bớt cái gì đó
▪ european central banks have scaled down their operations in south africa.
scale something down/back:giảm bớt cái gì đó
▪ the two companies have announced plans to scale back production next year.
▪ development projects were scaled down, and some proposals for new buildings were put on hold.

children.name: cut back
children.definition: /ˌkʌt ˈbæk/  to reduce the numbers of something or the time or money spent on something, especially because you can no longer afford to continue at the previous level:cắt giảm
examples: cut back on:cắt giảm trên
▪ her friends know that she is under stress and have warned her to cut back on her workload.
cut back something: cắt giảm cái gì đó
▪ our budget has been cut back this year.
▪ farmers have agreed to cut back wheat production.
cut something back: cắt giảm cái gì đó
▪ we have had to cut expenditure back in an effort to increase profits.
cutback/ˈkʌtbæk/ [countable noun]:sự cắt giảm
▪ schools and hospitals could suffer as a result of government cutbacks.
cut back in :sự cắt giảm trong
▪ there has been a significant cutback in the defence budget this year.

children.name: downsize/rightsize
children.definition: /ˌdaʊnˈsaɪz, ˌraɪtˈsaɪz/  especially american to reduce the number of people who work for a company, especially in order to save money:cắt giảm, thu hẹp
examples: ▪ they are downsizing the workforce in a desperate attempt to save the firm.
▪ advised to rightsize its operation, the company has shrunk to 2,000 employees.

children.name: pare down
children.definition: /ˌpeəʳ ˈdaʊn/  to reduce something by small amounts over a period of time so that the effect is not very serious or noticeable while it is happening:giảm dần, bớt dần
examples: pare down something:giảm dần, bớt dần cái gì đó
▪ the company has pared down expenditure and hopes to recoup its losses this year.
pare something down:giảm dần, bớt dần cái gì đó
▪ we have managed to pare our costs down to the absolute minimum.

children.name: rationalize
children.definition: also rationalise british /ˈræʃənəlaɪz/  to try to make a company more effective by getting rid of unnecessary workers etc:tối ưu hóa
examples: ▪ we are a small company, and we need to rationalize if we want to compete in this market.
▪ the company has done a lot to rationalize production.

children.name: wind down
children.definition: /ˌwaɪnd ˈdaʊn/  to gradually reduce the work of a company or organization so that it can be closed down completely:giảm dần
examples: wind something down:giảm dần cái gì đó
▪ the old sickness benefit system is slowly being wound down.
wind something down:giảm dần cái gì đó
▪ i want to return in a few years’ time - i’ve already started to wind the business down.

children.name: run down
children.definition: /ˌrʌn ˈdaʊn/  especially british to deliberately make something such as a company, an industry, or a public service weaker and weaker, by giving it less and less money:làm đi xuống
examples: run down something:làm cái gì đó đi xuống
▪ opposition leaders are accusing the government of running down the health service.
run something down:làm cái gì đó đi xuống
▪ they buy up rival companies then just run them down.

children.name: trim
children.definition: /trɪm/  to reduce something by a small amount that will not harm or change it very much, especially in order to save money:giảm bớt
examples: ▪ by trimming costs and improving service the hotel has now started to make a profit again.
trim something by 10% etc:giảm bớt cái gì đó 10%...
▪ the proposed bill would trim welfare spending by $5 billion.

children.name: streamline
children.definition: /ˈstriːmlaɪn/  to reduce the costs of something such as a service or industry by employing fewer people, reducing the number of things you produce or provide etc - used especially in business contexts:tổ chức hợp lý hóa
examples: ▪ the government is once again attempting to streamline the health care service in order to pay for tax cuts.
▪ the company announced it was to streamline its operations and close down three factories in the uk.

children.name: to make a written or spoken statement less forceful
tone down
children.definition: /ˌtəʊn ˈdaʊn/  to reduce the effect of a speech or piece of writing, especially by making the language you use less forceful:làm dịu bớt, hạ giọng
examples: tone something down:làm dịu bớt, hạ giọng cái gì đó
▪ i felt my letter was worded too strongly, so i toned it down a bit.
tone down something:làm dịu bớt, hạ giọng cái gì đó
▪ wagner was forced to tone down his remarks about his opponent when it became obvious that the attacks were costing him votes.

children.name: moderate
children.definition: /ˈmɒdəreɪtǁˈmɑː-/  to make your language more acceptable, especially by not swearing or being very rude:làm dịu đi, tiết chế
examples: ▪ we had to ask joan to moderate her language in front of the kids.
▪ she apologized at once, and moderated her voice.

children.name: dilute
children.definition: /daɪˈluːt/  to reduce the effect or force of an argument or belief, by accepting additional people, things, or ideas that may make it bigger but also weaker:làm giảm bớt
examples: ▪ right wing groups are determined to dilute the influence of the trade unions.
▪ they felt that their original aims and demands were being diluted.

children.name: erode
children.definition: /ɪˈrəʊd/  to gradually reduce the amount or value of something, especially money, wages, or profits over a period of time:bào mòn, ăn mòn
examples: ▪ over the years, the value of our savings and investments has been eroded by inflation.
gradually/steadily erode:bào mòn, ăn mòn dần
▪ high interest rates can gradually erode profit margins.

children.name: eat into
children.definition: /ˈiːt ɪntʊː/  if costs, rising prices, etc eat into the amount of money you have, they reduce its value:dần dần ăn mòn
examples: ▪ rising rents and travel expenses simply eat into any pay rise that nurses might get.
▪ theft from offices and factories eats into company profits.

children.name: deplete
children.definition: /dɪˈpliːt/  to reduce the amount of something to a level that is too low:tháo, rút, xả hết ra
examples: ▪ over the last few years, rainforests have been steadily depleted.
▪ he knew that the area’s rich plant life had been severely depleted by the huge herds of cows grazing the land.
▪ cfc is just one chemical that depletes the ozone layer.

children.name: chip away at
children.definition: /ˌtʃɪp əˈweɪ æt/  to gradually reduce the strength of something by repeated small amounts:bắt đầu giảm
examples: ▪ high interest rates can chip away at your profits.
▪ the group continues to campaign for the rights of disabled people, chipping away at old prejudices.

children.name: whittle away
children.definition: /ˌwɪtl əˈweɪ/  to reduce something by small amounts over a period of time, so that the final effect is very serious:làm giảm đi
examples: whittle away at:làm giảm đi
▪ congress is whittling away at our civil liberties.
whittle away something:làm giảm đi cái gì đó
▪ inflation has been whittling away the value of state pensions for the last fifteen years.
whittle something away:làm giảm đi cái gì đó
▪ lawmakers have gradually whittled the program’s funding away over the last few years.

children.name: a reduction in number, prices, levels etc
reduction
children.definition: /rɪˈdʌkʃən/  when a price, level etc is reduced - use this when something is reduced deliberately:sự giảm bớt
examples: ▪ we offer a reduction for groups of 10 or more.
reduction in:sự giảm bớt trong
▪ cleaner fuel has contributed to a reduction in air pollution.
▪ a reduction in working hoursa reduction of £10/$5/5% etc
a reduction by a particular amount:sự giảm bớt một lượng cụ thể
▪ there were reductions of up to 50% in some stores.
a big/huge/massive reduction:sự giảm bớt lớn
▪ there has been a big reduction in the number of issues the president addresses in any given week.
price reduction
sự giảm bớt giá
▪ several holiday firms are offering huge price reductions on winter holidays.

children.name: decrease
children.definition: /ˈdiːkriːs/  when something happens less than it used to:sự giảm đi, giảm sút
examples: decrease in:sự giảm đi, giảm sút trong
▪ there has been a 15% decrease in violent crime it has gone down by 15%.
a significant/marked decrease:sự giảm đi, giảm sút đáng kể
▪ in the last five years there has been a significant decrease in the number of deaths from heart disease.

children.name: drop b2/fall
children.definition: drop/fall/drɒpǁdrɑːp, fɔːl/  when a number or amount goes down suddenly or by a large amount:sự hạ, giảm, sụt
examples: drop/fall in:sự hạ, giảm, sụt trong
▪ charities have reported a 25% fall in donations during the past year.
a sudden fall/drop:sự hạ, giảm, sụt đột ngột
▪ universities are reporting a sudden drop in the number of students studying science subjects.
a sharp fall/drop:sự hạ, giảm, sụt đột ngột
▪ this year we have seen a sharp fall in profits.
dropnounlower
[ c usually singular ]a reduction in the amount or level of something
_the recent dropinmagazine subscriptions is causing some concern.

children.name: cut
children.definition: /kʌt/  a reduction in the amount or size of something made by a government or large organization - use this especially for talking about politics or business:sự cắt giảm
examples: cut in:sự cắt giảm trong
▪ cuts in the education budget have led to fewer teachers and larger classes.
a big/drastic cut:sự cắt giảm lớn
▪ there are to be big cuts in the health budget next year.
pay/job/tax cuts :sự cắt giảm lương/biên chế/thuế
cuts in wages, number of jobs, or taxes
▪ nurses are protesting about further pay cuts.
▪ the new management has promised that there will be no job cuts.
